title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a perfect score by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
According to the fundamental counting principle, if there are A possible outcomes for one event and B possible outcomes for another event, how many ways are there to pair the outcomes?

options.label: A
options.text: A + B

options.label: B
options.text: A - B

options.label: C
options.text: A * B

options.label: D
options.text: A / B

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected average score if a group of people randomly guess on a 10-question true/false quiz?
How many possible ways are there to answer a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing on a 20-question multiple-choice quiz with 5 possible answers for each question?
What is the expected number of questions a person would get right by guessing on a 20-question multiple-choice quiz with 5 possible answers for each question?
What is the name of the principle that states that if there are A possible outcomes for one event and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A times B ways to pair the outcomes?

options.label: A
options.text: Fundamental Counting Principle

options.label: B
options.text: Probability Principle

options.label: C
options.text: Statistics Principle

options.label: D
options.text: Mathematics Principle

multiple-choice.question: How many possible outcomes are there for each question on a true/false quiz?
What is the value of 2 to the 10th power?
What is the value of 5 to the 20th power?

options.label: A
options.text: 95 million

options.label: B
options.text: 95 billion

options.label: C
options.text: 95 trillion

options.label: D
options.text: 95 quadrillion

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of authentic narrative in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide breaking news updates

options.label: B
options.text: To connect people through universal and humanistic stories

options.label: C
options.text: To present bulleted facts and data

options.label: D
options.text: To interview official sources

multiple-choice.question: What are the three components of sourcing required in every well-reported piece of journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, social media, and eyewitness accounts

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: C
options.text: Academics, consultants, and authors

options.label: D
options.text: Stakeholders, experts, and the general public

multiple-choice.question: Who are considered official sources in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: People directly affected by an event

options.label: B
options.text: Academics and consultants

options.label: C
options.text: People with titles and expertise, such as company owners and spokespeople

options.label: D
options.text: Social media influencers

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources can provide the "why" behind an event or trend?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources

options.label: B
options.text: Overview sources

options.label: C
options.text: Unofficial sources

options.label: D
options.text: Eyewitness accounts

multiple-choice.question: How can journalists mine for compelling stories and anecdotes?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking routine and predictable questions

options.label: B
options.text: By asking surprising questions

options.label: C
options.text: By relying on official sources

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring unofficial sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of anecdotes in storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: To present facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: To provide a summary of the story

options.label: C
options.text: To breathe life into a story and make it more relatable

options.label: D
options.text: To distract from the main point of the story

multiple-choice.question: When is it important to convey information quickly and present bulleted facts and updates?

options.label: A
options.text: When telling a personal story

options.label: B
options.text: When explaining a complex issue

options.label: C
options.text: When a situation is urgent and action is required immediately

options.label: D
options.text: When writing a feature article

multiple-choice.question: What type of storytelling allows for a "slow dance of information"?

options.label: A
options.text: Breaking news updates

options.label: B
options.text: Feature articles

options.label: C
options.text: Personal narrative stories

options.label: D
options.text: Social media posts

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of using narrative personal stories in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To present facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: To connect people through universal and humanistic stories

options.label: C
options.text: To provide breaking news updates

options.label: D
options.text: To entertain readers

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of using artful solicitation of story in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: The story becomes less memorable

options.label: B
options.text: The story is reduced to just facts and data

options.label: C
options.text: The story becomes more relatable and memorable

options.label: D
options.text: The story is ignored by readers

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: What does Emily Dickinson compare a book to in her quote?

options.label: A
options.text: A ship

options.label: B
options.text: A frigate

options.label: C
options.text: A journey

options.label: D
options.text: A current

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when we "step onto the shore" of a new world through a story?

options.label: A
options.text: We retrace the footsteps of the authors or characters

options.label: B
options.text: We walk a mile in their shoes

options.label: C
options.text: We remain unchanged

options.label: D
options.text: We forget the story

multiple-choice.question: What are researchers in psychology, neuroscience, child development, and biology discovering about stories?

options.label: A
options.text: They have no impact on our point of view

options.label: B
options.text: They can only change our point of view temporarily

options.label: C
options.text: They have a unique ability to change our point of view

options.label: D
options.text: They can only shape our culture

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the impact of Samuel Richardson's "Pamela" on society?

options.label: A
options.text: It reinforced traditional class values

options.label: B
options.text: It challenged traditional class values and caused a ruckus

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on society

options.label: D
options.text: It was only popular among the upper class

multiple-choice.question: What is one way in which novels have helped shape the minds of thought leaders across history?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing a platform for debate

options.label: B
options.text: By inspiring theories such as Darwin's theory of evolution

options.label: C
options.text: By promoting traditional values

options.label: D
options.text: By providing entertainment

multiple-choice.question: What do recent studies suggest about our sense of being a hero?

options.label: A
options.text: That we are hardwired for competition

options.label: B
options.text: That we are solitary heroes in our own story

options.label: C
options.text: That we might be members of a shared quest

options.label: D
options.text: That we are not capable of being heroes

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to consider the context in which classic stories were written?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can dismiss their relevance to modern society

options.label: B
options.text: So we can appreciate their historical significance

options.label: C
options.text: So we can recognize that the terrain has changed and new perspectives are needed

options.label: D
options.text: So we can ignore their impact on our culture

multiple-choice.question: What is one way in which "Hunger Games" might lead us to think differently about capitalism?

options.label: A
options.text: By promoting the idea that the individual should prioritize their own interests

options.label: B
options.text: By highlighting the dangers of a system that prioritizes profit over people

options.label: C
options.text: By showing the benefits of a system that rewards competition

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the issue of capitalism altogether

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one way in which stories can influence us?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing a temporary escape from reality

options.label: B
options.text: By shaping our culture and influencing our ideas about life

options.label: C
options.text: By promoting traditional values

options.label: D
options.text: By having no impact on our thoughts or behaviors

multiple-choice.question: What is the final question posed by the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: What story will you try on next?

options.label: B
options.text: What is the impact of stories on our culture?

options.label: C
options.text: How can we apply the lessons of classic stories to modern society?

options.label: D
options.text: Why are stories important for personal growth?

options.label: A
options.text: To solve linear equations

options.label: B
options.text: To deal with extremely small or large numbers

options.label: C
options.text: To calculate geometric shapes

options.label: D
options.text: To analyze statistical data

options.label: A
options.text: The base number is the logarithm of the power

options.label: B
options.text: The power is the logarithm of the base number

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The base number is the power to which the logarithm is raised

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is easy to calculate

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has its own button on most calculators

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is used in computer science

options.label: B
options.text: The temperature of the sample

options.label: C
options.text: The volume of the sample

options.label: D

options.text: pH = log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Why do tears in our eyes have a pH of about 7.4?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the optimal pH for eye health

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is the pH of pure water

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the pH of the hydrogen ion concentration in tears

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not explicitly stated in the transcript

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect on the eyes of a pH of 8.4 compared to a pH of 7.4?

options.label: A
options.text: The eyes will feel itchy and red at a pH of 7.4

options.label: B
options.text: The eyes will feel itchy and red at a pH of 8.4

options.label: C
options.text: The eyes will feel no difference between the two pH levels

options.label: D
options.text: The eyes will feel more comfortable at a pH of 8.4

multiple-choice.question: How can logarithms be used in real-life applications?

options.label: A
options.text: Only in mathematics and science

options.label: B
options.text: Only in computer science and chemistry

options.label: C
options.text: In various fields such as chemistry, computer science, and everyday life

options.label: D
options.text: Not at all

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What is the earliest known form of telling time?

options.label: B
options.text: Sundial

options.label: C
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: D
options.text: Atomic clock

options.text: Gnomon

options.label: B
options.text: Pendulum

options.label: C
options.text: Quartz crystal

options.label: D
options.text: Stick

options.label: B
options.text: They require the sun to shine

options.label: C
options.text: They are too accurate

options.label: D
options.text: They are too expensive

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the speed of a boat

options.label: B
options.text: To indicate a predetermined passage of time

options.label: C
options.text: To measure the weight of an object

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was expensive

options.label: C
options.text: Because the motion of the boat did not affect it

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was fragile

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for scientific time today?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A continuous count of minutes based on sundials

options.label: C
options.text: A continuous count of hours based on hourglasses

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to keep track of time?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can sleep in late

options.label: B
options.text: So we can accurately communicate with people all over the world

options.label: C
options.text: So we can ignore schedules

options.label: D
options.text: So we can waste time

multiple-choice.question: What was a problem with the American railroad system in the mid-19th century?

options.label: A
options.text: Each railroad used the same standard time

options.label: B
options.text: Each railroad used its own standard time

options.label: C
options.text: The railroads did not have clocks

options.label: D
options.text: The railroads did not have trains

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of time zones?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
